title: 114_hr4783
content: The "Commercializing on Small Business Innovation Act of 2016" extends termination dates for SBIR and STTR programs until 2022 and amends administrative funding provisions. The "Commercializing on Small Business Innovation Act of 2016" extends termination dates for SBIR and STTR programs until 2022 and amends administrative funding provisions by increasing the percentage of the budget allocated to SBIR from 3.46% in 2018 to 4.50% in 2022 and each fiscal year thereafter. The Small Business Act is amended to increase the budget allocation to SBIR from 3.46% in 2018 to 4.50% in 2022 and beyond. Additionally, the STTR program will receive 0.50% in 2018 and 2019, and 0.55% in subsequent years. The Small Business Act is amended to increase the budget allocation to SBIR from 3.46% in 2018 to 4.50% in 2022 and beyond. The STTR program will receive 0.50% in 2018 and 2019, 0.55% in 2020 and 2021, and 0.60% in 2022 and beyond. SEC. 4. REPORTING REQUIREMENTS. Annual reporting requirements under the Small Business Act have been amended to specify deadlines for submitting reports to Congress and the Administrator, with the deadline for submission set for December 31 and March 30 of each year, respectively. The Small Business Act has been amended to require agencies to submit annual reports to the Small Business Administration by March 30 each year, with standardized reporting formats specified. The Small Business Act now requires agencies to report annually to the Small Business Administration by March 30 each year, with specific reporting formats outlined. The Small Business Act now mandates agencies to submit annual reports to the Small Business Administration by specific deadlines, such as March 30 and June 30 of each year, with detailed reporting requirements outlined. The Small Business Act requires agencies to submit annual reports to the Small Business Administration by specific deadlines, including March 30 and June 30 of each year, with detailed reporting requirements specified. The Small Business Act mandates that Federal agencies must report on the use of administrative funds to the Administrator by March 30 each fiscal year. Failure to submit the report will result in the agency not being eligible for fund authorization unless the report is submitted along with an additional report. If a Federal agency fails to submit a required report, they will not be eligible for fund authorization unless the report is submitted along with an additional report detailing plans for timely reporting. SEC. 5. INDEXING AWARDS FOR INFLATION. Section 9 of the Small Business Act is amended to reorganize and modify certain subsections, including the redesignation of subparagraphs and the removal of specific clauses. Additionally, a new subsection is added at the end. The Small Business Act is amended to reorganize subsections, remove specific clauses, and add a new subsection regarding awards under Phase I and Phase II of SBIR or STTR programs, with maximum amounts of $150,000 and $1,000,000 respectively, adjusted for inflation. SEC. 6 amends the Small Business Act by changing authorization to a requirement for insertion incentives. SEC. 7 clarifies the eligibility of certain small businesses. The Small Business Act is amended to clarify the eligibility of certain small businesses for receiving awards under the SBIR and STTR programs within 180 days of the enactment of the Commercializing on Small Business Innovation Act of 2016. The Small Business Act is amended to clarify that small businesses described in subparagraphs (B), (C), and (D) of section 3(p)(3) are eligible to receive awards under the STTR program within 180 days of the enactment of the Commercializing on Small Business Innovation Act of 2016. SEC. 8. COMMERCIALIZATION ASSISTANCE PILOT PROGRAM. Section 9 of the Small Business Act is amended to include a Commercialization Assistance Pilot Program, requiring covered agencies to implement a program to award eligible entities with a second sequential SBIR award within one year of the enactment of the Commercializing on Small Business Innovation Act of 2016. The Commercialization Assistance Pilot Program mandates covered agencies to award eligible entities with a second sequential SBIR award. Agencies must not exceed 5% of their total SBIR budget for this program, which will end on September 30, 2022. The Administrator will enforce a matching requirement. The Commercialization Assistance Pilot Program requires agencies to allocate a portion of their SBIR budget for awards to eligible entities. The program will end on September 30, 2022, and a matching amount from a third-party investor is required for any award received. Funding from ineligible sources is not permitted for matching. The Commercialization Assistance Pilot Program requires a matching amount from a third-party investor for any award received, with ineligible funding sources not allowed. Awards may not exceed certain limitations and will be distributed during the Phase II award period of the recipient eligible entity. The Commercialization Assistance Pilot Program requires eligible entities to submit an application with matching funding information to receive a second sequential SBIR award. Funds awarded can only be used for specific purposes. The Commercialization Assistance Pilot Program awards funds for research and development activities that accelerate commercialization. Recipients are chosen based on how the funds could help them commercialize their research. When awarding funds under the commercialization assistance pilot program, agencies consider the potential for research commercialization, technical feasibility, improvements to the commercialization plan, and the progress of small businesses in Phase II activities. The evaluation criteria for awarding funds under the commercialization assistance pilot program include assessing the progress of small businesses in Phase II activities, the potential for research commercialization, technical feasibility, improvements to the commercialization plan, expectations of third-party funding, and the likelihood of commercial and societal benefits. The Comptroller General of the United States is required to submit an evaluation report to relevant committees within 3 years of the enactment of the Commercializing on Small Business Innovation Act of 2016. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit an evaluative report to congressional committees within 3 years of the Commercializing on Small Business Innovation Act of 2016 enactment. The report will include a summary of commercialization assistance pilot program activities, detailed results achieved, and the number of small businesses receiving awards. The Comptroller General will submit a report to congressional committees within 3 years of the 2016 Act, detailing the results of commercialization assistance pilot programs, including awards received, commercialization rates, employment and revenue growth, success comparisons, and demographic information of participant companies. The report will include a comparison of commercialization success between pilot program participants and Phase II awardees, demographic information of participant companies, funds usage at each agency, third-party funding sources, program effectiveness analysis, and recommendations for program improvement if made permanent. The report will include a comparison of commercialization success between pilot program participants and Phase II awardees, demographic information of participant companies, funds usage at each agency, third-party funding sources, program effectiveness analysis, and recommendations for program improvement if made permanent. Definitions for covered agency, eligible entity, and eligible third-party investors are also provided. Phase II award and a Phase II sequential award from the covered agency to which such entity is applying for a second sequential SBIR award. Eligible third-party investors include small business concerns, venture capital firms, individual investors, and non-SBIR government entities. Ineligible sources of funding include internal research and development funds, non-cash forms of funding, and funding from owners. The sources of funding for eligible entities include internal research and development funds, non-cash forms of funding, funding from owners, and funding obtained through loans or debt obligations. Section 9 of the Small Business Act is amended to increase the participation of underserved populations in the program by providing outreach and technical assistance. Additionally, a conforming amendment removes the waiver authority for certain uses of funds.
